name: Kepler-341
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-341 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-341 is a star with 0.9770000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.02 times its radius. It is located 3520.72 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-341 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-341 b

Kepler-341 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.20 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-341.

The mass of Kepler-341 b is 1.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 b is 1.18 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-341 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-341 c

Kepler-341 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.01 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-341.

The mass of Kepler-341 c is 3.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 c is 1.7 that of Earth. At 3.46 Earth masses, Kepler-341 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-341 d

Kepler-341 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 27.67 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-341.

The mass of Kepler-341 d is 4.21 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 d is 1.85 that of Earth. At 4.21 Earth masses, Kepler-341 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-341 e

Kepler-341 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 42.47 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-341.

The mass of Kepler-341 e is 5.05 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 e is 1.99 that of Earth. At 5.05 Earth masses, Kepler-341 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-341, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
